text.p: These are the highlights of the main Sao Paulo and Rio de Janeiro newspapers this morning.
GAZETA MERCANTIL
-- MERCOSUR COMPLAINS ABOUT IMPORT FINANCING RESTRICTIONS
Mercosur countries have complained about Brazil's decision to introduce restrictions on import financing without any prior notice or consultation.
-- VARIG LOSS INCREASED NINE TIMES

National airline Varig posted a 1996 loss nine times greater than the previous year's under Brazil's Generally Accepted Accounting Principles, but inflation adjusted results showed a net profit of 91.7 million reais, up from a 1995 loss of 7.5 million reais.
FOLHA DE SAO PAULO
-- CPI DIVIDED OVER SUMMONING BANKS

Members of a parliamentary committee (CPI) investigating a multi-million dollar fraud involving state and municipal bonds are divided over summoning representatives of large banks which bought suspect bonds.
-- DOGS KILL SIX-YEAR-OLD GIRL IN RIO
A six-year-old girl was attacked and killed by three German shepherd dogs Rio when she jumped over the wall of a relative's home to collect a toy she had forgotten.
O GLOBO
-- FEDERAL POLICE TO PROBE CHILD PROSTITUTION IN MANAUS
Federal police is joining authorities of the state of Amazonas to investigate child prostitution in the city of Manaus. Police suspect that minors are being sold across state borders.
-- NINE POLICE OFFICERS ARRESTED FOR BRUTALITY
Nine police officers have been arrested after amateur film footage shown on television revealed how they beat, robbed and killed people in a Sao Paulo shantytown.
-- DIVER DIES TWO YEARS AFTER ACCUSATIONS

A diver, who denounced bad working conditions at Brazilian oil installations and platforms two years ago, has died in an explosion in 293-meter deep water while he was repairing an oil duct on one of the deep sea wells.
-- Reuters has not verified the stories and cannot vouch for their accuracy.
((--Simona de Logu, Rio de Janeiro newsroom 5521 5074151))
